39317568.review:
This is easily the best puzzle game I've ever played in my life. There really are very few games like it. Stephen's Sausage Roll is an incredibly polished game. The controls and mechanics are simple, yet allow for an insane amount of variety in puzzle design and playstyle. Each level of the game is challenging in its own way, from the very first level to the last. I beat this game in 21 hours, and never once was I bored. 

The insane thing about Stephen's Sausage roll is the way in which it utilizes its simplistic mechanics. While other puzzle games like Portal and Talos Principle will construct level packs around certain gimmicks (think repulsion gel and turrets), Stephen's Sausage Roll introduces next to no new concepts as time goes on. There are really only four new concepts that get introduced over time, but these concepts are mechanics that already exist with the character. An example of this is walking on sausages. The character has always been able to walk on top of sausages, but this move isn't required to solve any puzzles until the third "world". Stephens Sausage roll takes one simple concept of moving sausages onto grills, and really only does that for the entire game.

However, this game isn't for everyone. It really is incredibly hard. Thankfully, the game includes a rewind button, so you are never really punished for making a mistake on a puzzle. Other puzzle games would force you to restart where stephen's sausage roll doesn't. If this feature wasn't included, I would have hated the game. The rewind button really allows you to not be afraid to make mistakes.

Overall, I thought the game was really, really, really good. If you like hard puzzle games, this game is for you. It is easily the best puzzle game I've ever played.

39289205.review:
If you like hard puzzles, I cannot recommend this game enough. It's similar to The Witness in a number of ways (though smaller in scope): there are no tutorials, and the game lets you discover the mechanics for yourself. Each new area blows your mind in a unique way, and "aha" moments abound. Highly recommend.

39249686.review:
Stephen Lavelle, aka increpare, has created in Stephen's Sausage Roll a tidy microworld that constantly grows in logically reasonable yet unexpected ways, achieved solely by altering previously known bits of terrain. It eschews graphics, music, and story in favor of difficult puzzle gameplay, and astonishingly, the end result is one of the best games I've ever played.

Though it may start a bit slowly, every time a "new" mechanic is presented, it manages to do so in such an innocuous and natural manner that once you understand how the mechanic works, it seems impossible that it wasn't present in previous levels. And that's the real beauty of the game: everything presented WAS in the previous levels, but just slightly past the veil, out of sight. Even in the very final stretch, there are novel presentations of mechanics that aren't present in any of the previous levels. Playing this game feels like watching a magician pull objects out of a hat, or clowns coming out of a clown car; when you think there could not possibly be any more mechanics, it turns around and reveals an entire new category of possibilities.

Overall, the levels are handcrafted to a degree of precision and exactness that I've never seen in any other puzzle game. The controls, though they're pretty clunky, are tightly integrated into the level design. By restricting certain types of movement, the levels are able to have a sort of maze-like progression of moves that can be fully mentally solved before even making a move. It's especially noticeable at the start of the game, where there's also a much smaller margin of error than in later levels.

An absolute stunning display of game design.

39186836.review:
Being honest here, you probably won't like this game. So if the price point is making you second guess purchasing it i'd suggest you skip it... at least until it goes on sale.

Even with that being said, i can whole-heartedly reccommend this game if a brain-teaser type puzzle is what you're looking for. This game is full of small puzzles (and a few intimidatingly large ones) that may have you stumped at first but soon after have you feeling damn clever for figuring them out.

Overall, the most welcome feature in the game is it's simple control scheme.  Using W/A/S/D you can move forward and backward in the direction that you're facing and rotate 90 degrees to face another direction. Outside of that you have 3 other keys that allow you to quit the current puzzle with no penalty, reset the puzzle to start again, and an unlimited undo button that will allow you to undo each move that you've made all the way back to the point where you first boot the game up. But just because the control scheme is simple, that doesn't mean that the gameplay is simple. In fact, one of the first things you'll have to figure out is how to move about the levels effectively. 

And the simplicity of it all doesn't come without a few surprises. At first it may appear that the only puzzle of the game is to roll and push the sausages around to get them all cooked, but then your fork comes into play more and instead of just pushing them around you have to skewer them too, and now there's ladders too, and you're rolling around on top of a sausage? And how did this sausage end up on my head like that? It's a lot less of new and more complicated features being added, and more of encountering situations which, up until that point, hadn't even come into play. The game isn't teaching you anything new, you just happen to figure it out while looking for a solution.

If i had to give a comparison to gauge the type of gameplay you can expect from this game, I would compare it to those sliding block puzzles where you have to move all the other blocks around in the grid to get the one target block out of the gate. Its a lot of moving things around and seeing if you're any closer to a solution and slowly undoing your moves to see if you missed something somewhere. It's not "exciting" exactly, but it sure is satisfying when the solutions become apparent to you.

And as always with cleverly designed puzzles, your difficulty may vary. Some may find a majority of the puzzles simple, others won't be able to make heads or tails of the first collection of puzzle the game offers them. Personally, i felt stumped for a good while before everything started clicking for me, and then a puzzle that i had stepped into earlier which i felt was far too challenging for me to ever complete suddenly became a playground to practice the new assortment of tricks i had learned. And as i rolled that last sausage onto the grill, i wondered why i figured it was too difficult in the first place.

38346254.review:
It's over, I cooked my last sausage. I feel complete. I feel empty.

Stephen doesn't care about the game design best practices. No tutorial here, no gradual learning curve, you're thrown into an unknown world, with the first puzzles already being hard. You're a stranger to this world, don't expect it to be easy and welcoming. I left my first play session with a bitter taste in my mouth, hesitating to come back. This game is more expensive than it appears to be worth, and I just spent a precious time of my life cooking sausages with a ridiculously hard to control character. But I went back, passed the first island, and discovered a new game mechanic. But this mechanic wasn't brought by a new item to obtain, no, it was here all along, but the environment was just not exposing it. I feel there are other mechanics, hidden, just waiting for me to discover them. I continue, eager to explore to find these mechanics, and there are a lot, and the puzzles are ingeniously crafted to extract the last bit of juice each mechanic can offer. And when you think you're finished, Stephen reveals yet another mechanic, pulling it from the bottom of the sea right to your face, promising you more hours of frustrating puzzles. But no, the end is near, you feel it, and you must prove to yourself you're better than these sausages, you're alive, and you must complete this game. And I finished it, I waited so long for the end to come, I wanted to say "I did it!", but now I feel empty. These puzzles were mind-bending, always pushing me to the limits, forcing me to explore new ideas, making me go further, extending my brain capacity to think outside of the box. And this is it, every sausage is cooked, and I won't benefit from another brilliant sausage-based puzzle until the day I'll be cooked myself.

I am not kidding when I say this, a few islands in and it hasn't let up in surprising me every step of the way.

I will say that stage is pretty daunting when you see it, and.. it does take some will, trial and error to make it through.. but I believe in you.

There isn't a time element (which I cannot understand in stage based puzzle games, if I know the solution what is the purpose of measuring my fastest time smashing buttons in precise timing and order?), no step counter, nothing of that sort, only a little dude with a fork and the goal of cooking weenies. I give this game 96.33333332 out of 103.4

36956809.review:
Stephen's Sausage Roll is a hard sell in many ways. The graphics are extremely blocky and simplistic, the music is mostly procedurally generated and kept in the background, and there's initially very little in terms of story or any sort of context. There's no tutorial to ease new players into the fiendishly difficult puzzles - many people with only a passing interest in the genre will likely quit after seeing just the first few levels. The vague trailer, description and hefty price tag probably don't help either.

Still, once you strip all of that away you're left with one of the best puzzle game experiences available on Steam.

The basic premise for each level is that there are some sausages, some grills, and armed with your fork you must cook every sausage and return to the start to complete the level. The levels are made of tiles, and sausages are two tiles long, have two sides that require to be cooked, and cannot be overcooked or dropped into the ocean. Every level plays around with this simple premise, and almost all of them manage to introduce a new twist or encourage a different method of thinking - the game has almost no filler or tedium. This applies to the levels themselves: each level is tightly designed such that almost every traversable tile or obstacle carries some significance to the puzzle, and the later puzzles introduce a surprising amount of verticality (the '3D puzzle game' description really doesn't lie). The puzzles start off difficult and only get harder from there - you can expect to spend upwards of an hour trying to solve a single puzzle. In fact, one potential negative may be that some puzzles do appear too early relative to the player's familiarity with the game ([spoiler]one puzzle in world 2 comes to mind[/spoiler]) and may prove extremely intimidating. However, the payoff of figuring out the trick to each puzzle and solving it feels incredibly rewarding, and it does convey a real sense of progression in terms of mastering the mechanics of the game.

An obvious game to compare this to is The Witness. Past the graphics and exploration aspects (for which The Witness certainly wins), the underlying idea is much the same. Both games don't explicitly reveal anything about their mechanics, instead leaving it to the player to figure the rules out. This concept is as essential to the game as the puzzles themselves, but Stephen's Sausage Roll does this more subtly, only allowing the player to experiment as much as the levels accommodate for it. Unlike The Witness, which have distinct types of line puzzles, it doesn't feel like new mechanics or abilities are outright introduced to the player; rather these abilities are discovered through normal play; sometimes even on accident. It's these discoveries that lead to the most mindblowing moments of the game; it's as though an entirely new layer of the game opens up, presenting multiple avenues for more complexity and teasing many potential applications of these mechanics. There's also the story element that The Witness has taken some flak for - here the story is simpler and told far more directly, but it still manages to be surprisingly endearing [spoiler](and perhaps a little disturbing)[/spoiler].

So all in all, would I universally recommend this game to everyone? Absolutely not - this is a puzzle game at its purest that would appeal to a very specific niche of players, and you'll need a lot of patience and perseverance to overcome each of its challenges. If you're willing to make that commitment, then Stephen's Sausage Roll is well worth the asking price, and it may well be one of the most rewarding experiences you'll have in a puzzle game.

36244269.review:
史蒂芬的香肠卷（以下简称香肠）是一款无与伦比的，精妙绝伦的，秒天秒地的解谜游戏。

用两个字简单来说：神作！！！

我单薄的语言可能完全无法讲出这款游戏的杰出之处，但这真的是解谜游戏的天花板，益智游戏的领头羊。

我不知道看这篇评测的玩家玩过多少解谜游戏，解谜游戏一般有三种方式构造难度曲线：
1.复杂而精确的操作
2.引入新的机制、道具、互动
3.越来越复杂而精妙的谜题

其中1的话愤怒的小鸟，切绳子等等都算吧，需要精确和掌握时机。
2的代表作是传送门系列：光板，激光，折射砖块，凝胶。
当然不少游戏这些元素是夹杂其中的，但仔细想想，只有3才是一个解谜游戏深度的体现，1和2都脱胎自动作游戏和“强行”增加的难度，或许可以做得很精彩，但却有失解谜游戏的本质。
而这款香肠却牢牢地抓住了3，把解谜这个元素做到了极致。

游戏从一开始把所有东西都展现给你看了，在整整6个大关，没有一样新东西（第六大关的勉强算有），只有越来越巧妙的谜题和“还有这种操作”的惊叹，游戏自带撤销键，不会要求不能失误，于是你可以放心把精力集中到谜题上。

这个游戏关卡设计上就一个字：难。
我们一般认为好的关卡设计应该像任天堂那样，手把手、潜移默化地慢慢教你，让你在成就感中自我学习。但这款游戏不是，虽然在大关上依然存在难度曲线，但每一大关是同时把所有关卡开放给你，而且有时你一关也想不出来。这是关卡设计的另一种极致，在挫败感中学习，然后在解开谜题的一瞬间，获得巨大的满足感，可以说，这是解谜界的黑魂。

虽然游戏内核还是推箱子的变种，但其实这个游戏的第一大关就已经是很多游戏的最后一大关的难度了，而且如此密集的关卡（第一大关有16关），没有任何两关的核心思路是相同的！每一关都要经历：“这怎么可能过得去”到“居然还有这种操作？”的转变。可以说，第一大关很大程度上就是推箱子的极致了，精简而美妙。但如果游戏仅止于此，那么它也配不上神作的称号，仅仅是一个有些新意的推箱子罢了。

到了第二大关，这款游戏才让人眼前一亮，第一大关蹩脚的操作突然有了理由，你手上的叉子突然被赋予了意义，梯子的加入也让游戏的前景突然变得开阔起来，香肠不再仅仅意味着香肠，叉子不再意味着叉子，它们被赋予了某种超于“物块”以上的意义。

而到了第三大关，这款游戏才初露峥嵘，如果说第一大关、第二大关是眼前一亮的推箱子，第三大关则一口气展露了作者的野心，不再能简单地将推箱子定义这个游戏，一个平面游戏的机制到三维层面会是怎样？这款游戏的答案几乎完美，滚动、默认静止、踩香肠，种种设定合理而有深度，复杂而不冗余。让游戏界面的立体化有了原因，

第四大关只有六关，我认为更接近于第三大关的补充，加入了香肠的转向的要素，我第一次碰上时简直拍案叫绝。这一大关我认为是过渡关，之后的关卡更加巧妙。

第五大关的主题再次把我惊到，叉子又不再仅仅是手臂的延伸，而是又一件可以利用的道具，游戏的深度在一次又一次的延伸，却没有向其他游戏那样，加入爆炸、粘性等等机制，异或呆板地设置三星这样的东西。从头到尾，都是叉子和香肠，简单却复杂，我认为这才是解谜的最高境界。

第六大关有最多的28关（我觉得其实可以细分为前半部分和后半部分），这一大关，才是作者终于全力放飞自我的地方，几乎每一关都要在大地图进行安排才能过关，使以前的大地图又有了意义，活动块的加入也进一步加深了谜题的深度。

[spoiler]而也正是这一大关，展现了这个游戏的全貌，游戏中有一定的剧情文本，需要走到特定的地方才能阅读，也正是这些文本，使游戏进一步升华，使一切，都被赋予了意义，包括香肠的来历，为什么要烤香肠，等等一切都有了至少看似合理的解答。我认为比起解答，这更像一个隐喻，一种对虚无主义的诠释：人生没有意义。当然这部分只是我个人观点，但看到自己操纵的主角变成了最后一根香肠时的震撼是无以言表的。[/spoiler]

游戏作者非常高冷，在商店页面只有一句A simple 3d puzzle game.，深深嘲讽着我。
有人问作者为什么不加入成就系统，作者说：“我觉得我的游戏不需要成就系统。”
在游戏感谢名单的最后，有这样一段话，我也非常想送给大家：

I don’t love all of you , but I would if I could.

35999347.review:
Imagine a puzzle game where, rather than waste time on fancy graphics and characterisation, a developer channeled all of their time and energy into completely mind-opening level design. That is, at its core, what Stephen's Sausage Roll is. It starts off simple enough, almost like some mobile game, however even at that early stage many of the puzzles appear to have obvious solutions that just don't [i]quite[/i] work. The second area is where things start to really pick up, and for the first 5 areas, each area introduces another technique for puzzle solving. The neat thing is how these techniques come into play; the second area, for instance, introduces a trick involving an interaction between sausages and walls (I won't go into more detail because it'll spoil the surprise). However, in the first area you would never come upon this trick, as the first area has no walls. Areas 3, 4, and 5 introduce similarly game-changing techniques, giving the player more tools to attack the often fiendish problems the game poses. However, these 5 areas (comprising roughly 2/3 of the game in terms of sausages grilled) serve mainly as a tutorial for the final section of the game, which is filled with puzzles so original they could almost be new games by themselves. This section is reminiscent of the second half of Portal, in that the lines between individual puzzles become more and more blurred.

There is a narrative of sorts, although much like Portal this only really picks up during the final section, and it never interferes with gameplay in any way. I decided to wait until I finished the game before writing this review, and I'm pleased I did because the ending is both satisfying and conclusive (there are [spoiler]220[/spoiler] sausages in the game). In terms of difficulty i would say it is somewhere around the level of a Zachtronics game, however there's a big difference in style, as the puzzles in those games don't tend to have one intended solution and revolve around system design.

If you're still wondering about the price, I have two suggestions for you:
[olist]
[*] Try to get through the first area within the refund time (should be doable, depends if you're feeling smart) and go to the puzzle in the second area called "The Tower" (you'll know it when you see it). This is the first time the game gets really interesting, and should give you a taste of what comes later.

[*] Watch an unedited playthrough ([i] not a walkthrough [/i]) of the first area, where someone figures out how to solve the first set of puzzles. Notice how many times they get fooled into thinking there's an easy option; only to find they've wound up in a dead end, and how even the smallest puzzles require quite complicated solutions. This should help with suggestion (1) if you think you need it, as well as clearly demonstrating the ingenious design of the game.
[/olist]
In my opinion, despite its initial appearance, this is pretty much the best puzzle game there is at the moment, and i would recommend it to anyone and everyone. Worth every single penny.

35958473.review:
This game is truly "all killer, no filler".  I'm only 1/3 of the way through, and I can unequivocally say it's one of the hardest puzzle games I've ever played.  It's also by far the most rewarding!  There is zero extraneous content: it's all puzzles, puzzles and more puzzles.  Puzzles are concentrated in smallish "islands" that are fairly compact, so there isn't the running-around-looking-for-more-puzzles issue that makes The Witness a chore at times.  All the puzzles are completely fair; there are no "environmental" or meta-puzzles included here (at least, none that I've encountered so far).  And yet, some of the puzzles are so brutal you will be very sorely tempted to look at a walkthrough.  DON'T!  If you do, you will ruin your entire enjoyment of the game.  The essence of the game is trying to solve a puzzle, failing, rewinding, trying again, and over and over until you finally figure out the trick that makes this puzzle doable.  You will be 100% certain over and over again that a particular puzzle is impossible, only to solve it later.  When you do solve a tough puzzle, you will feel like the smartest person alive!  Puzzles don't require brute-force trial and error but rather a way of looking at a situation with fresh eyes to see what you missed the last time.  Although I'm not a mathematician, I imagine that solving an SSR puzzle is a lot like proving a tough theorem, with false starts, lemmas ("I just need to get this sausage here and then...") and finally, enlightenment :-)  I woudn't recommend this game to anyone who isn't a hard-core puzzle fanatic, though, or it will drive you crazy.   If you do get it, my advice is to not worry so much about solving the puzzles at first and just concentrate on exploring the possibilities in a particular puzzle.  Sometimes you'll stumble upon the right approach right away, but other times you will beat your head against a particular problem for literally days until you finally get it.   One strategy that has worked well for me is to work backwards.  Imagine what the final configuration of the sausages could be, and then figure out how to get there.  Another tip is that you should try to figure out what every part of the puzzle is there for.  I guarantee that there is nothing in any puzzle that is not necessary, so if there is some unusual part of the puzzle, you can bet that there is a good reason it has to be there.

Although this game is agonizing at times, I've never played a game that was better at making me solve problems logically.  If you are a serious puzzle game fan, you absolutely have to play this game.

EDIT: Now I'm about halfway through the fourth world, and I'd like to add another bit of advice.  Sometimes, you get it into your head that a puzzle can only be solved if you get a particular sausage into a particular configuration.  However, a lot of the time there is another way to solve the problem, and if you don't let go of your preconception you will go crazy looking for something that isn't there.  I know this is vague advice but it will make sense when you are banging your head against a hard puzzle.

35668669.review:
The Nathan's Hot Dog Eating Contest of spatial-planning puzzlers.  This is definitely the most substantial, most difficult and best logic puzzle game I've completed.  It's better than its classic predecessors like Sokoban and Atomix.  It's better than Braid and Limbo, two of my other favorite indie puzzlers. [Added: it's better than their acclaimed followups, The Witness and INSIDE, as well.  At least on the puzzle side.]

This game is a historic achievement in puzzle design.  The ground rules (the physics and the vocabulary of objects) are clear enough from early on, but their ramifications become clear only gradually as more complex situations arise.  The creator wrests a fantastic depth and variety of puzzles out of a simple ruleset, with endlessly surprising and novel solution techniques.  

As a result of this richness, there are (justifiably) a large number of puzzles.  You'll have to work long and hard to win.  (I think it took even longer than the 48 hours showing on my account, more like 60+.)  I felt there was a slight dip in variety/quality of puzzles in one environment---the animal-themed one---but that section was also easier than the surroundings, so it was a welcome break and not a big deal.  

The story-telling in this game is done by readable plaques. The story is very sparse and almost completely enigmatic for most of the way through; if you persevere, you'll eventually be rewarded with a final area that delivers a rich and satisfying (though still enigmatic) story.  No spoilers, but I felt it really delivered something original and compelling---you wouldn't guess from the silly title of the game.

 Anyway, this game should hold great appeal for any determined puzzle-solver.

35617083.review:
This is the best puzzle game ever made in terms of mechanics, and it's not even close. You can finish it in 36 hours, and that's 36 hours of zero messing around. This game doesn't ask for the same solution twice, not ever. The game starts with almost zero instructions and literally every single detail has a reason for existing, even the controls. The controls are a bit odd and take some time to learn, but mastering them is part of the experience. After going to the first level there's already a massive difficulty spike and I can't even call it that because the game really is the most difficult puzzle game in the world that also manages to be fair and smart. You have a rewind button for every move and a reset, but no hints. After beating each puzzle you really feel like you learned something that the developer intended for you to learn, and that thing usually doesn't appear a second time unless it's really basic. 

Even though this is a 10/10 game and the masterpiece of it's genre I absolute cannot recommend it if you don't have the following criteria: you need to be really smart and have a solid background in puzzle games. Otherwise you literally won't be able to finish the game on your own (which is the whole point), and you are going to reach a wall really quickly because of it (maybe in the first minutes).

35560251.review:
An extremely in-depth exercise in the subgenre of 'sokoban' or block-pushing puzzle games. If those are the kinds of games you like, you can enjoy this as a very long and clever one of them. If puzzle games aren't usually your thing, this one is relatively approachable. Don't be misled by people calling it hard; the designs are such that a puzzle will first appear impossible, but experimenting will gradually teach you the concepts necessary to solve it. Do be aware that this game is a very 'pure' experience; if the first five minutes don't appeal to you, neither will the rest. 

I played most of this game alone in the mornings before work, but I'd recommend putting it up on a projector with friends and beers. Or strong tea.

I hesitate to give this game a thumbs up. The pacing is rough at best, there's no real tutorial or instructions from what I can tell (and while usually I find this unnecessary, this game could REALLY benefit by showing the player a few basic techniques), and honestly I think it should have tank controls.

Some have said the game can't have tank controls because of mechanics later in the game, and I have not finished it, but as of yet I have not reached a point where they're impractical. Any time the controls wouldn't work, the game locks you into an "alternate" (or at least limited) control scheme, which would be barely different than tank controls. In a game that focuses so heavily on the orientation of your character, I'm amazed they have the controls like this.

That said, the puzzles are really, really good and inventive and satisfying to complete. There's really no other puzzle game like this that I'm aware of. The rewind mechanic is also the best of it's class. I would recommend the game under the acknowledgment there is a STEEP learning curve, both with the controls themselves and basic techniques, but challenging puzzles that will keep you on your toes.

34983823.review:
This is a puzzle game that is a lot of fun. There are 87 levels in total, and every level throws a wrench at you at a different angle; i.e., every level has you doing something unique, some new orientation you haven't tried before or just a completely new mechanic. You will occasionally get frustrated by the lack of instructions and the forced mousing around to find/master a new game mechanic, but perhaps these annoyances are necessary to better enjoy the full flavor of the game? The controls are simple: just WASD or arrow keys, but these simple controls are complexified by way of the terrain and, of course, the requirement of cooking the sausages.

Is it worth 29.99 USD? I beat the game in 29 hours, which meant that I basically paid 1 dollar every hour to play. Yes, that was worth it to me. Although I am sure you could pick it up cheaper later on (It was in the Humble Bundle once).

As you play the game you notice that you will master old techniques that you were utterly confused by earlier, but even if you try to understand all of the mechanics you have previously been shown, nearly every puzzle requires a new way of thinking--whether that be through rolling, pushing, spoking, or causing fall a sausage. 

One of the great things about this game is that each level is compact. This means that you can get a map of the current level in your head. When you exit the game, if you are like me, you will be thinking of ways to overcome the level in your head when you are not playing--I used a pen and paper during my work lunches to solve some of the harder levels! And I wouldn't be surprised if many others did too.

There is a story to the game, but it is connected by loose straws. The story is made to be strange, and to attempt to give reason as to why you are rolling giant sausages on a remote island. When you complete the game it may be fun to read fan theories about the story.

I was thoroughly entertained during my playthrough, and I do recommend it to those persons who are interested in "a simple 3d puzzle game."

34313268.review:
¡Vaya juegazo de rompecabezas! Lo pillé en un bundle pero vale su precio completo. 

Es un juego duro, difícil, y en ocasiones malévolo puesto que algunos niveles están pensados con mucha mala leche. 

Partiendo de unas mecánicas simples, que se van añadiendo nuevas conforme avanzas, este señor (alias Increpare; Stephen para los amigos), crea problemas de gran complejidad, es absurda la cantidad de combinaciones diferentes que se pueden crear.

El creador del juego ha tenido que poner muchísimo tiempo en la creación y diseño de los niveles, están muy cuidados. Tanto es así que si bien hay elementos comunes, cada nivel es un mundo que aunque recuerda cosas de otros, la forma de resolverlo casi no coincide en nada. Puede que algún patrón se repita, pero en general  cada nivel es un soplo de aire fresco; un rompecabezas nuevo en el que tendrás que exprimirte los sesos para resolverlo. 

Cuando te enfrentas a un puzzle, la experiencia acumulada de haberte enfrentado a los anteriores ayuda, pero menos de lo que uno cabría esperar.

La música es casi inexistente, suenan un par de notas sueltas muy de vez en cuando. Pero es relajante. 

Los gráficos los describiría como funcionales, son lo justo y necesario para representar el entorno nada más y nada menos.

Decir que al igual que pasa en otros juegos como The Witness, no se te explica nada, tú mismo tienes que aprender las mecánicas por ti solo con prueba y observación.

Si te gustan los desafíos y tienes paciencia, este juego y el mimo que el creador ha puesto en él merece mucho la pena.
Afirmaré que es uno de los mejores juegos de rompecabezas creados hasta el momento.

Stephen's Sausage Roll might just be the best puzzle game I have ever played. I don't want to sound like I'm parroting Jon Blow and his praise for the game, but it's honestly literally true.

It really feels like the guy who designed these puzzles is right there, daring you solve it, and it feels so good when you finally figure out the solution. There are some puzzles that are basically elaborate jokes at your expense (if you've cultivated a bad habit over the previous few puzzles, he makes sure you learn never to repeat that again). Some levels are really intimidating but actually have such simple solutions, and then vice versa. The way new mechanics are introduced feels so natural, and sometimes leaves you shocked that a thing you thought was impossible is actually routinely expected of you now.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys puzzle games and isn't afraid of a challenge.

There are puzzle games that are difficult just for the sake of being difficult. But it takes true genius to make a game that is tough but fair, and requires solutions that are, at times, exquisitely elegant.

Even when the levels seem initially possible, the relatively small size of each puzzle prevents the game from ever feeling like it's asking more than a little patience and experimentation.

33290967.review:
After a mind-distortingly frustrating first hour, I have to conclude that this game is too difficult for me.  It took me a good 5 to 10 minutes just to figure out where the first puzzle was.  The first one I happened to encunter had 3 sausages on it and I had no clue what I was supposed to do with them.  Eventually I gave up and found another one with 2 sausages.  Still clueless.  I gave up and found what must be the intended first puzzle, and finally ascertained what you're supposed to do with these sausages.  I then looked around and found each puzzle containing only 1 sausage and was able to complete them.  Then I started looking for the ones that had 2 sausages, and it started to get very frustrating again.  After my first hour, I completed maybe 5 or 6 total puzzles.

This game does NOT hold your hand, or explain anything to you, and there is only like 3 puzzles that are truly "beginner" level.  It ramps up in complexity and difficulty FAST after that.

At it's root, the puzzles are kind of like those sliding puzles you might have played before, where you need to move pieces around in a confined space, sliding them into empty spaces and pushing them against each other to complete the picture.  Only in this game, as you move the pieces around, there is a mechanic (I don't want to spoil it because I was legitimately shocked and had a "eureka" moment when I first discovered what exactly you're even supposed to do!) that "disables" your ability to move the pieces in certain ways into certain spaces.  Your movements are therefore more limited than you'd otherwise have in a sliding piece puzzle. So you have to get things lined up and make all the right moves from the very beginning of each puzzle, or else you make it impossible and have to rewind or start over to get it right.  Often you don't know that the move you've just made (could even be the first move in the whole puzzle) makes it impossible to solve, but you don't discover that until 20 moves later that there is no way to complete it, and even then you may do it 20 different ways before realizing that it was that very first move that you were getting wrong all along.

The game does have a rewind feature to undo moves instead of having to start over, but often it's just easier to completely start over.
 
There is a certain logic and tactic to doing these puzzles that my brain just isn't getting.  I struggled intensely to finish the easiest couple of levels in the game, and then hit a total wall and felt angry and feustrated for the next 15 minutes being unable to find another puzzle I could complete.  So after close to an hour I have given up, and I'm not sure I'll ever go back.  It just feels way more difficult than I was expecting or that I feel capable of doing.

For the record, I love puzzle games, and have completed every puzzle in The Witness, Talos Principle, Portal 1 & 2, etc without looking at any guides, but this puzzler just pummels you with a very steep difficulty right at the beginning.  At least, for me.

Overall, I like the premise of the puzzles and think the concept is simple and clever.

However, the controls are awkward.

It should feel like you’re manipulating the puzzles to figure them out, but in this case I feel like I’m spending more time wrestling with the movement than solving the problems.
This takes me out of the experience.
Suggestion: Have WSAD for movement and Q/E to rotate.
Do not mix rotation and movement in the same buttons.

A second issue, is that the puzzle solutions can be long and the basic undo function is not useful enough.
Perhaps adding a way to set checkpoints to save the puzzle state would help.

As it is today, it’s an interesting premise for a game but is not fun to play.

32707411.review:
The game is very, very hard from the very start. The progression in difficulty after the beginning is reasonable, but the game begins with a difficulty cliff that is frankly mystifying. It would have been very easy to throw in a half dozen puzzles that explored the basic mechanics at the same pace that future puzzles expand on them. The only explanation I can think of is the hope that reviewers would fawn over the difficulty fetishism - and I guess the gambit worked since that's the main thing anyone seems to say about it.

In general, the game has brilliant ideas, asking you to make some brilliant intuitive leaps. When it works, it's very interesting, and it will keep impressing you with how far it can stretch the puzzles without giving you anything more than the fork you start with.

Unfortunately, most of the best ideas are trapped in sokoban-style games that feel more like the Tower of Hanoi than they do The Witness. All of the really brilliant intuitive leaps are trapped beneath a wet blanket of time spent figuring out the particular sequence of moves that you more or less understand - you'll frequently find yourself working through a level, figuring out the "trick", and then sighing as you resign yourself to figuring out the particular sequence for the rest of the level.

It feels like all of the really interesting insights come at the cost of an awful lot of tedium. All of the new and intriguing concepts are stuck behind a lot of sokoban that is not particularly novel or fun.

If you enjoy sokoban, this game is probably an absolute delight. If you don't, I don't think the legitimately smart elements of the game are worth the time spent on far less stimulating aspects of the puzzles.

[i]I've seen things you people wouldn't believe. Attack ships on fire off the shoulder of Orion. I watched c-beams glitter in the dark near the Tannhauser Gate. And I’ve played and finished Steven’s Sausage Roll, now what else has life got to offer? I highly doubt it…[/i]

-----------

As a player, Steven’s Sausage Roll gives me existential crisis (literally not metaphorically), I kept dwelling on the thought of whether would it be possible for me to encounter another puzzle game that’s half as good as this Sausage Roll in the rest of my life, at least in the foreseeable future, the possibility is rather remote. For a puzzle enthusiast, this is really dreadful. 

So here comes the only suggestion this pointless review is gonna offer, to prevent you from making the same mistake as I did: [b]If you do enjoy puzzle games and wish to extend your happy hour with this genre in general, you may want to consider postponing your first contact with Steven’s Sausage Roll indefinitely. [/b] Otherwise, many other puzzle games you used to enjoy would either feel like chewing cardboard or simply child’s play. Embrace Steven’s Sausage Roll only when you’re ready, ready to venture into the end of the world, the end of space and time, that kind of ready.

I’m not saying that Steven’s Sausage Roll is the hardest puzzle game I have played, considering how players these days mistakenly value difficulty over quality, especially within the puzzle genre. No, I have played harder ones, but never have played any puzzle this ingeniously and sophisticatedly made. 

Thus, as a creator myself, I am completely overwhelmed by the shadow it cast. Its total supremacy was like an unspeakable existence that you can never imagine yourself to surpass or even come close with, even exhausted a lifetime of effort. Yet, it still exists there, silently and solemnly, like the Mount Everest, to frustrate you, to defeat you, to deprive you of all hope! And yet in the end, to motivate you…

Anyhow, its otherworldly excellence has far exceeded my verbal skill, I’ll have to conclude this pointless review with this crude statement: 

[h1]Does the world need another puzzle game (especially Sokoban-originated ones)?
Not after this.[/h1]

32159095.review:
I bought Stephen's Sausage Roll because Jonathan Blow said it might be the best puzzle game ever made, and while I don't really agree with that, I do think it may well be the most perfectly designed puzzle game ever. 

The gameplay consists of rolling sausages which are 2x1x1 spaces such that each quadrant of the suasage (top and bottom of both spaces) touches a grill space exactly once. You do this by moving your avatar, a 1x1x1 person holding a 1x1x1 fork, forwards and backwards and rotating left and right. Despite that description, the control scheme is relative to the player, not the avatar, which was mildly infuriating to me at first but serves to make the mechanics more congruous later on. The game doesn't so much introduce new mechanics to you as much as help you accidentally discover them, and each flows naturally from the base mechanic in such a way that you'll wonder if you didn't already know them and just hadn't had an opportunity to use them yet. All of the levels are intertwined when navigating the world, but when you enter one the rest of the world drops away leaving only the relevant bits. And every single one of those bits has a purpose in every level. In fact, as far as I can tell, there is not a single surpufluos object in the entire world.

Though many of the puzzles took a long time for me to work out, their design and the unlimited undo meant that I never felt frustrated or annoyed. Only one that I can remember felt a tiny bit tedious.

If I have a complaint about the game, it's that it's a bit long, with the last third or so feeling like a bit of a slog to me.

If you're a fan of puzzle games at all, you're going to want to own this one.

Never before have I felt such conflicting and fluctuating attitudes about my own mental abilities as I have with Stephen's Sausage Roll. Much like how Dark Souls makes you feel utterly weak with an challenge that ultimately makes you feel god-like after overcoming it, Stephen's Sausage Roll uses every level to make you feel like dumb sack of shit, until you solve it and you feel like you can take on anything... until you see the next level.

When I played The Witness I would come across a puzzle and say "Nope, I'm  too dumb for this one" and the game would be like "yeah, go do something else and git gud", where this game says "Well, you don't have a choice. You'll do it, you'll like it, and ask for seconds... Psst, dude, don't worry, you got this".

There's several points in the game where the difficulty seems to jump too high, and yeah, watch that step, it's a doozy, but half the challenge of them is just overcoming how daunting the task is. If you beat The Great Tower, you're ready for anything the game will throw at you, I don't care how dumb you are, all you need is courage. 

The game rewards being adventurous and trying out bizzarre things, mostly because of the brilliant undo system, but also because the simple mechanics you learn on the first level are more far-reaching than you would give them credit for.

Ouais, en regardant les snaps, on se dit “oh, encore un clone à deux balles de Sokoban”.

Sauf que non, pas du tout du tout du tout. 
Nul “reverse-engineering” ici, pas plus qu'une recherche de la séquence de mouvements parfaite. Souvent, même, plusieurs approches sont possibles. Non, la difficulté réside dans l'intention de l'auteur de sans cesse vous pousser hors des sentiers battus, à inventer des solutions à ce qui paraît impossible. Le génie du jeu est de ne pas demander justement de génie : il faut être curieux et savoir prendre son temps. C'est sans doute l'un des plus accessibles jeux du genre, même si son unicité me pousserait plutôt à dire qu'il n'appartient à aucun autre genre que le sien propre.

Le [i]roulé de saucisses sauce Stephen[/i] utilise son propre langage visuel, et même si son vocabulaire est heureusement limité pour nous épargner, les règles de grammaire et les exceptions sont foison. Au fur et à mesure, la moindre aspérité, le moindre espace deviendra lourd de sens et d'implications. 
Et à la fin, quand vous devrez vous détacher de ce petit chef-d'œuvre, de son atmosphère relaxante et stimulante, de sa mythologie empreinte de l'air du temps, il vous en coûtera comme de toute séparation d'un être chéri.

32004659.review: "It does what it says on the tin." Great spatial reasoning puzzle game. Long, challenging, and rewarding. You walk around in a small open world and solve puzzles. Introduces new mechanics through discovery. For example, some puzzles are designed so that you'll accidentally notice that you can do something with the sausages even though it's not part of the solution. A few puzzles later, that thing you stumbled upon before will be the main mechanic for a series of puzzles. The game is very hard, but some reviewers and websites try to exagerate the difficulty to be dramatic. The first few puzzles are not that bad despite many people saying you could get stuck and quit on the first puzzle; I don't think that's true at all. A handful of the puzzles later in the game will probably stump you for an 1-3 hours, but the rest you will figure out in 10-30 mins or so. Tons of people seem to think the tower puzzle near the beginning of the game is really hard and maybe a deal breaker or something. It is intimidating, but it's also really obvious what you need to do and you just need to mess around a bit to make it happen. There is a small bit of story to add flavor to what you are doing too. Controls are purposefully weird, but since that type of control is built into the puzzle design, it works. Great game overall, it felt like a great achievement to finally beat it (took me 35 hours). Graphics are great too; this isn't a game with hyper-simple graphics like it might first appear, there is actually a ton of detail going on.

I spent nearly thirty hours manhandling some thick, juicy sausages, and though this is certainly the most intellectual acuity I've had to expend on [i]that[/i] particular activity, I'm ready to say what an immense pleasure it was to see and hear all those weiners release their meaty spray.

But enough about my weekends.

[i]Stephen's Sausage Roll[/i] is a sublimely designed puzzle game that astounds with both its complexity and simplicity. At any given moment, you have four possible inputs. Out of those four inputs, based on your location, the sausages' location, the burners, and the terrain, you must cook both sides of your sausages.  The sausages are moved intuitively, rolling or sliding based on the direction they're pushed from.

you'd think that with such limited number of inputs, the puzzles would be easy.  you'd be surprised, then, to find that even the simplest puzzles will take some time to wrap your mind around. it's a hallmark of a great design: narrow inputs with limitless depth of possibilities (c.f. some games that are incredibly wide but disappointingly shallow).

31707720.review:
IF YOU HAVE TIME AND PASSION TO CONCENTRATE IN PUZZLES, YOU SHOULD BUY THIS. 

I just cleared this game and saw the ending. Here's my comments about the characteristics of the game. And I don't want to spoil anything about the final chapter of the game, after the "Dead End" puzzle, which is my favorite. You should feel the same shock with that specific puzzle. 


- This game features NO TUTORIAL PUZZLES for any of the mechanics. Instead it throws one of the harder puzzles one can make with that mechanics on your face as soon as a new mechanic is introduced. This means every single level is challenging. I mean SUPER DUPER HARD. Sometimes you'll waste more than 30 minutes as soon as entering one puzzle to think about, like, 'Is this possible? Seriously, I don't even see any move I can make.' Especially in the last world. 

- Though, all of the mechanisms are surprizingly and EXTREMELY INTUITIVE and doesn't need any further explanations. This is very important and it's the most satisfying point for me. It follows rules of physics very well (but you have to take care of the physics, like the law of action and reaction). 

- The game DOES NOT feature any new rule at any instance of the game. It does feature new mechanics for each chapter, but they are not new rules. Like, you are able to walk on the sausages or turn around with a sausage on your head, which is nicely intuitive. But you can't turn around with sausages on your fork or step into midair, rules are never changed or added. Also no new objects are introduced. There are the player character, sausages, solid blocks and grills only. 

- Puzzles are excellently designed, every single block (or hole) is there for a reason. Feels like a genious designed the puzzles.  Most of the puzzles make you to think outside of the box. Sometimes you'll find out the puzzle is impossible to solve from your knowledge. Try to do some weird moves, or moves that you thought it sets the puzzle stuck. Furthermore, even if you did come up with the idea, the puzzle remains hard. This is not the kind of the game that you can solve in 1 minute after you find the trick. 

- The story was very interesting and fun to me. The story really begins in the last chapter so you don't need to rush. It's simple, weird and satisfying (maybe it's only me). I also love the ending. Yeah. 

- You can't redo puzzles you've already solved directly. However you can use 'load game' menu to take yourself to whatever auto-save you want to, so it doesn't matter so much. (Thanks for [SeHa] j0bs of pointing this out)



After all, this is one of the best puzzle games I've ever played. It stands with Witness or Recursed in my mind.

Whether or not you think this game is worth $30 heavily depends on how smart you are and how easily you get frustrated. I can totally picture someone buying this and not being able to solve a single puzzle after a couple hours. It's that hard. It's blindfolded Rubik's Cube hard. I think the high price is specifically to discourage all but the most hardcore puzzle gamers from trying it. If the game were more accessible, there'd be much more negative reviews from people who had no clue how to roast a single set of sausages successfully.

This is not one of those games that makes you feel really clever most of the time you're playing it like The Witness or The Talos Principle. This game makes you feel stupid and overwhelmed with deceptively simple-looking puzzles until you actually manage to reason your way through it. Every puzzle I thought "Woah, I have NO clue where to even start, I'll leave this one for later and go to one of the easier ones" before realizing that WAS one of the easy ones. If you are a brilliant person (or think you are), this will be a good way to test your reasoning and spacial abilities.

I picked it up in a humble bundle for $10 and am glad I finally got a chance to experience the game for myself without spoiling any of the solutions. This is one of those games I honestly don't think I could complete if I had a hundred years and two equally smart people helping me, but I'm interested to see how far I can get.

[h1]The Most Frustratingly Rewarding Simple 3D Puzzle Game[/h1]
https://youtu.be/XJMtnGPkzZ0

+ Decepively simple. You might look at the trailer or start a level and think "This game looks easy, I got this no sweat!" ...but the game will taunt you as you get stumped on each and every level.
+ The gameplay is pretty simple and easy to learn. The goal is to cook sausages on the burner. You must cook the sausage once on both sides to complete the level. If you cook them twice or knock the sausage into the water you lose. 
+ "Undo button" which allows you to easily traceback your steps without having to restart the level from the beginning.
+ Very challenging, great for veteran puzzle solvers. One thing that makes the game so hard is that each level is on a very small grid which limits your available moves severely. One wrong move and you will be in deadlock, so you have to carefully plan out each move.
+ relaxing soundtrack
+ Just a personal note, but this is one of those game that you have a friend or family member play and laugh at them while they sturggle to get past the first few levels.

- The game is incredibly difficult from start to finish. This may throw off casual players who will likely not finish 5 levels before giving up.
- I feel like the movement controls could be improved a bit. Sometimes you want to turn around, but your characters will turn in the oppisite direction causing you to accidentally hit a sausage, which can be a bit annoying.


[Side Note: I seldem mention price points in my reviews, but this game is currently priced at $30!... that's a bit steep and may impact how much you enjoy the game]

31514852.review:
If you want to cut your teeth on the Final Boss of box-pushing puzzle games, then have I got the game for you.

Right out of the gate SSR offers a somewhat uneven mix of real head-scratchers and what I can only describe as pity puzzles, but quickly reveals itself to be the sort of puzzler that mandates particularly extensive sessions of staring at the seemingly inconsequential number of tiles onscreen and poking experimentally at them until something starts to click. This demands a little more patience than I ordinarily have, but I was starting to appreciate the design as I acclimatized to it.

Then I arrived at The Great Tower level (in only the second subsection of the overworld), which all at once foists about 4 times more pieces on you than you've dealt with previously, while simultaneously introducing a Z-axis and the concept of using pieces as platforms mid-puzzle.

SSR does have a well-executed and forgiving Undo function with basically unlimited storage which is a great thing to have up until the time spent rewinding would outweigh the time spent to simply restart the puzzle and do over; the only way it could be made practical on a level that large would be if you had a full-on timeline scrubber like in the rerelease of Duke Nukem 3D.

There's patience, there's logic, and then there's [b]this.[/b] I play puzzle games to try and [i]relieve[/i] stress, not the other way round. It's a solid design, and I'd probably recommend it to the REALLY die-hard logicians and puzzle fanatics. To the sort like me who enjoy puzzles but prefer there to be some sort of ceiling to their complexity, Gaben help you if you're going to try and soldier through this thing. I would even call Infinifactory a lot more accessible than this is.

30109817.review:
"A simple 3D puzzle game" is an apt description - simplicity is where its greatness lies. It is notorious for being difficult, but while it can take a bit of time to figure out the rules that govern the movement of your character and the sausages (some of these rules feel a bit arbitrary), after you do the difficulty gradient is negative. It felt like the middle of the game was where it peaked in difficulty.

The game allows you an infinite stack of undos, since it's easy to make a puzzle unsolvable. The best puzzles are those where you really have to use constructive reasoning to rule out sets of possible moves, and there are lots of puzzles like that. For some others the trick is relatively simple and it feels more like trial and error as you try to avoid moving sausages to inaccessible positions, particularly towards the end of the game.

The level design is consistently creative. Each level feels genuinely different from the last; the game only repeats tricks to introduce new ones. To top it off, each level is integrated into a huge overworld; on activating a puzzle, the unnecessary land drops away and you are left with some sausages to roll and a grill. The overworld is fun to explore, and the freedom to tackle puzzles - within an area - in the order you choose means you can postpone difficult puzzles for later. Without the overworld the game simply wouldn't be as interesting, or as user-friendly.

The graphics are as you see. Crude, but for a game like this, the most important thing is that it's easy on the eyes. The music is subdued and soothing. The game is relaxing to play and doesn't try to assault your senses.

Is £20 a misguided price for this game? Yes. Do you get your money's worth of utility from it? Absolutely. It's quite a long game, and you get to solve puzzles which genuinely require thought.

I played the DRM-free version and I think I spent about 20 hours finishing it, give or take 5. You can get both the DRM-free version and a Steam key for the same price, and they share the same directory for save data.

29756751.review:
Stephen's Sausage Roll must be one of the purest puzzle games to come around in years. It is 100% created for its mechanics and the way they are incorporated into the staggering amount of puzzles is sheerly baffling. 

Somehow each level showcases a new concept. This is an incredbile feat as there are no "powerups",
special keyboard prompts or any other standard gaming conventions to promote variety: the sausages, fork and Stephen are all that are needed. 

This game is not for the feint of heart. The begining levels are likely to take upwards of 5 to 10 minutes each to figure out how to properly navigate a perfectly cooked sausage and it is very likely some puzzles will take hours to solve. There is not an unfair puzzle, no red herrings or cheap tricks, just pure rational problem solving.

The puzzles in this game have two general ways of being solved. The first is organically as you move around the level. Slowly you'll see movements that will get you closer and closer to your goal, its then just up to putting those movements in the correct order. Its a very satisfying feeling slowly building up your understanding of the puzzle until you can see the whole picture and have those tasty sausages pop away. 

The second way problems get solved is by uncovering the underlying mechanics of the game and this is where it truely shines. There are no tutorials to teach you any mechanic other then moving and rewinding mistakes, a flawless mercy that lets you undo any action step by step for as long as the current play session (or if there is another limitation I've never expeienced it after rewinding dozens of minutes away just by holding down a single button). Its so well implimented that you can even undo exiting a level, making sure all those minutes of sausage rolling will never be in vein. Every time you discover a "new" mechanic is a moment of awe as your brain tries to process how many new possibilites this new option will provide. Do yourself a favour and never, NEVER, look any puzzle up. There are logical solutions to all of them and you will eventually be able to create it; a moment that will give you pure bliss until the next puzzle.

The art style at first feels very basic but the more time you spend with this game the more you understand the benefits of its simplicity. Everything has been created to make the best possible puzzle expeience and this art style allows for a clear sense of spacing for all aspects of the level as well as being able to frame most levels so that they fit in one screen. The little details like particle effects on flowers, the day-night cycle, the different sound effects for everything and even the music all show the attention to detail that this game went through. 

All in all this is one of the greatest examples of not only the puzzle genre but of games in general. If more games could treat their mechanics with such care and expand them as far as Stephen's Sausage Roll the industry could only benefit.

28583370.review:
In my opinion, this is the best puzzle game ever made. Nothing else even comes close.

Not a single puzzle is filler. The difficulty curve is harsh because you're expected to learn fast (though this is not a completely good thing). Every puzzle introduces a new idea. Naturally, some puzzles will turn out to be easier than others, since you'll come across some of these ideas on your own. But you won't come across all of them, and the game will astound you with how much depth its simple set of mechanics holds. Every time you discover something on your own, and you say to yourself, "Wow, I wonder if there'll be a puzzle that takes advantage of this trick"? There will. There always will.

Not a single puzzle is cheap. They all stretch your understanding of the world and the mechanics just a little bit, sure, but no big rule is ever introduced without being first shown to you in a safe, straightforward environment. There won't be a mechanics switch in the middle of the game where your expertise in one area of sausage-rolling will become irrelevant. There will be plenty of puzzles where you say "I think I could make (some situation that I've never seen before) occur. What would happen if I do that?" and then sometimes, when you do that, you'll find that you've solved the puzzle. Stephen's Sausage Roll does manage to be astonishingly creative in the ways it bends its mechanics, but these ways never really felt very annoying because they were always extremely consistent at their core.

Not a single puzzle is annoying. Once you figure out the core idea, then it's very straightforward to perform the correct set of actions and solve the puzzle. There's no mechanical skill at all. There's no huge puzzle where you have to do ten things in a specific order. There's no irrelevant garbage that will get you stuck looking down an incorrect path. There's an undo button and a restart button, both well-implemented (you can even undo a restart), so making a mistake is okay. The hard part is meant to be figuring out the puzzle, and ONLY that.

And finally: not a single puzzle is condescending. They expect a lot from you, and each puzzle is basically the hardest possible puzzle that can be made using its specific idea. Once again, there are zero red herrings in this game, and an idea is never repeated twice. That's pretty damn impressive.

The game's graphics are blocky and very vibrant, which makes it super easy to see what's going on everywhere. The music is kind of nondescript atmospheric stuff, good for really long stretches of thinking. The sounds are cute and used sparingly and appropriately.

This game isn't perfect. It's a very linear game towards the end, and frequently you'll have only one puzzle to do. I wish you could take a break from later puzzles and try out other ones when you're stuck. The early game does a much better job of this.

Still, I recommend this game whole-heartedly. It's head and shoulders above anything else I've ever seen.

Sokoban-style box-pushing puzzles have been reinvented: they are now oblong meat products, and you are a man with a fork who must see them all cooked and consumed on a strangely beautiful island of voxel art and ambient music.

The core mechanics are unchanging from puzzle to puzzle - cook all four parts of a sausage evenly without burning it - but the shape of the sausages, the changing level geometry and your character taking up two tiles forces lateral thinking and understanding at a level that can only be called brilliant.

Each separated island introduces new puzzles and new complexities, but nothing as crass as new abilities - your simple fork-swinging suffices from beginning to end. You just don't realise until you're confronted with raised terrain and ladders, overhangs and stacked sausages what the full implications of your seemingly limited movement abilities are and how they can be used to manipulate your sausages on and off the grills.

Another bit of genius from increpare - at the very least, you'll feel like a bit of a genius after solving each deceptively simple bit of sausagery.

I was on the verge of refunding this game within the first hour of playtime. I couldn't cook a single sausage. I went back, gave it another chance, and finally cooked one. Then another. And another. And for the most part, I was. And that moment came over and over until all the sausages were perfectly cooked.

Most of the puzzles are constructed to teach you something new about the game and how to play it. In a way, even though this game is deviously hard at times (most of the time), it spurs you onward. Most puzzle games are content to be difficult and inscrutable, easily causing the player to toss them aside in frustration. So much care has gone into each of the puzzles in this game that it feels like the solution is just beyond your reach, so you rarely go into a puzzle without having any real idea of how to go about things. There are some stumbling blocks, sure, but if you take the time and effort to just observe and experiment, you're bound to find something that can help you cook those damned sausages.

Stephen's Sausage Roll is likely the hardest puzzle game I will ever complete. There have been harder puzzle games, but none that have spurred me onward to see it through to the end.

27283231.review:
First off, this game is *difficult*. But it's a fair difficulty if you have experience with puzzles. If you don't have prior experience but want a difficult puzzle game you can actually complete, you would be better off playing either English Country Tune or Snakebird first. Go ahead and pick up those two titles first, and complete them. Those are easier than this, but still quite difficult for a first-timer.

Now, a review for those of us who are actually experienced in puzzle games (but somehow haven't bought this?).

Stephen's Sausage Roll is a puzzle game that, first and foremost, prides itself on having some of the most ludicrously difficult puzzles, yet having merely a small handful of fairly simple rules. Think Fish Fillets, Hana no Puzzle, and Snakebird. You play as the titular Stephen, who has crashed her ship on the Island of Wisdom and must presumably find her way back home. However, the island is strange; it has sand and grass as you'd expect from an island, but it also has mysterious pink cubes, metal grilles, and ghostly versions of Stephen herself.

Oh, and Stephen for some reason holds a giant fork. Don't ask why, because I don't know. Maybe that's her ship's anchor or something.

At this point, you're probably wondering what the gameplay is like. I understand; the trailer doesn't show anything, you don't want to spoil yourself too much by reading reviews on external sites, but you're not sure if this game really is worth the 23GBP. So I'll say this much:

The pink cubes are sausages, the metal grilles are grills, and you have to grill each sausage by pushing them onto the grills. Take care not to burn them or lose them in the water. It's like Sokoban, but more difficult due to the giant fork that Stephen's swinging around, making it annoying for her to move. But that's where the "puzzle" part of the game comes from.

It's really not too easy to describe the difficulty of a puzzle, but I'll give it a try; on one level, the obvious path of "push both sausages together" ends up burning one of them. Many people get stuck here when they try and push one of the sausages out the way and fail. On another level, there is a moat around the two solitary grills in the centre, and you somehow need to get the sausage over the moat and onto the grill. Then there's the tricksy Clover level, where you think you have the solution, but need to avoid getting trapped. On yet another level, you have to somehow juggle around three sausages on a small island, while making sure that none of them push each other off the island.

Many times, when I've shown the game to my friends, they've all played a level for 15 minutes and simply given up, claiming that the level is impossible.

Well, that's just the first island. The second island unlocks once you've completed all the puzzles in the first island and not before, so if you're not a completionist for puzzles, this game is probably not for you.

In the second island, there is a new game mechanic introduced; but unlike many other games, this game mechanic had always existed; it was just unapplicable in the first island (no spoilers as to what the mechanic is), and it's at that point that you really gain an appreciation for just how well-designed this game is, if you hadn't already gleaned it from the previous levels.

Basically, what I'm saying is this; if you're not good at puzzles, then your 23GBP would be better spent on The Witness, The Talos Principle, or a combination of cheaper puzzle games; you would probably just get frustrated at this game and refund it after getting stuck on a bunch of levels in the first world. If you're good at puzzles, this should already be in your library, so go play it now.

Oh, and don't worry about the infamous "Tower" level. It's really not that large of a jump in difficulty.

26821130.review:
Stephen's Sausage Roll is a game that the developer doesn't want normal people to buy, it seems. The description is literally, "A simple 3d puzzle game.", there is one video that shows you nothing about the game, and it's priced at $32 CND.

Fortunately, I'm here to tell you to get off your ass and to buy this wonderful game. The graphics are alright, the music is OK, but the puzzles are sublime.

In each level, the goal is the same: cook all the sausages and exit the level by standing on the exit level sign in the right orientation. You cook sausages by pushing them over a grill. Like in sokoban games, you can't pull the sausage (yet...), only push it. Another huge wrinkle is that sides of the sausage can only touch the grill once. If you touch a cooked side of a sausage to the grill, it will be burned and you fail the level. This little wrinkle will make you pull your hair out in some levels as you try and figure out how the hell you are going to maneuver the sausages around so they get cooked properly. A neat thing about the game is that if you fail, you can still continue playing the level, which might help you figure out how to play it.

You'll have a section (part of an island) that has a number of puzzles for you to solve in any order, so if you get stuck, you can try another one (until you get to the last puzzle of the section). Once you complete a section, a new section will open up with more puzzles.

Your little guy has tank controls, which you will find extremely useful, as turning to the left or right near a sausage will push it in different directions. A nice detail is that the all of the puzzles make up the island section. When you activate a puzzle, the rest of the island drops away into the sea, leaving you on a tiny puzzle island.

Each section introduces new mechanics into the game. First you'll just be pushing the sausages, but then you'll be stacking them, skewering them (you would think this would make things easier, but no! You can't turn when you have a skewered sausage!), walking on them...

I would say that these levels are on the level of Snakebird, though I found many of them easier than Snakebird's puzzles (maybe I'm better at sokoban games than I know?). These are the kind of puzzles that you walk away from frustrated, but come back to a few hours later with the solution. This is the game where there are so many ah-ha! moments that make you feel smart. You have no idea what to do at first, but eventually you get better and better. You might not see solutions at first, but you begin to see where you need to go to solve the puzzle, and then work backwards from there. It's wonderful!

If you're having trouble, there's a community guide that has all the solutions, which is super helpful (though not as much when I was playing because it wasn't complete!).

It might be expensive, but I took 36 hours to solve all the puzzles and it was worth every penny.

Deli-cious sau-sages.

Made from succulent pigs. Don't like rolling sausages for moral reasons? This game might be for you.

The geometry of the common marbled sausage is round. This property allows them to be rolled. Rolling a sausage is like playing the piano - hard to master, but very rewarding. Burning a piano is also frowned upon. Much like sausages.

If you lose a sausage at sea, it is lost. Where do you go, little sausage? No High Arts can save you now, my fortune telling friend.

There was a great review here, once. Now, there is something even greater.

This is undoubtedly the most well built puzzle game's I've played.
Every puzzle is elegant in its construction, drip feeding you the ability to unravel the game's mechanics. Something as simple as a wall next to a three tile wide open stretch can fundamentally change how you view an entire stage. Nothing is placed without purpose.

25569713.review:
类型：关卡解谜
评分：5（-5分~5分）

没有宏大的场景和引人入胜的背景故事，
仅仅靠着各种意想不到、令人惊叹的玩法组成的高难度谜题让众人折服。
谢谢小红米送我这么优秀的作品~

[h1]游戏内容：[/h1]
一个抽象的小人，一把攥紧的叉子，这是我和我的全部家当。
几根浅色的香肠，几片火红的地炉，这是我神圣的工作。
叉子如此巨大，每次转身都会扫掠过周身的空地；
叉子如此沉重，我只有正面双手持握才能把住；
叉子如此宝贵，只有失足坠落才能将我们暂时分开。
每一次接手新的工作，
总有崎岖的道路阻拦我将香肠变成美味的烤肠，
而我，
不论多么艰难，
都能完美地展现我顶级大厨的功力：
用推、滚、扫、叉的娴熟手法提供恰到好处的火候，
均匀地烤熟香肠每一寸表面，
不焦不生，外酥里嫩。
溢出的油脂滋滋作响，诱人的香气四处弥漫。

之所以能成为顶级大厨，
相信和我坚韧的毅力与永不服输的高昂斗志有关。
我从来不相信会有无法完美烤出的香肠。
每一根香肠都是我的珍宝。
我会给每一根香肠最完美的新生。
无论多么艰难。
我知道曙光和胜利在前方。

[h1]具体参数：[/h1]
一共六大章，
前五章每章有十来个左右的小关，第六章关卡更多些。
每一小关需要烤熟提供的香肠，香肠数目不定，
没记错的话是1根到9根之间，
整个游戏一共有215+5根香肠需要烤熟。
别看关卡如此之多，其花样之繁多，
竟感觉没有哪两关解谜思维是完全相同的。

[h1]感想：[/h1]
看着大厨辛勤烤肠，
这几近40个小时的时光里，我。。。：
苦闷，震惊，叹服，恍然大悟，懵逼，拍手叫绝，毫无波动甚至还想睡觉，喷血，感觉自己宛如一个智障，感觉自己就是一个天才，充实，心好累，妈个鸡，我还能再战十盘！

关卡游戏的通病是容易让人感到单调乏味，
不得不说本作也是有一点点的，
但是它关卡设计上的卓绝绝绝绝绝很好地弥补了这一缺点，
所以我仍给它5分高分。
缺点显露的具体症状为：
单调和思考上的乏累常常让人玩一会就想休息。
所以虽然我游戏时长是38小时，
实际上时间跨度是好几个星期。

24735728.review:
[h1]Stephen’s sausage roll[/h1]

两个字：神作

谈游戏前先说说作者有多高冷:
1.	游戏名暂且不说，简介视频中也完全没有介绍这游戏的基本解谜机制。游戏简介正如你看到的：A simple 3d puzzle game.没有其他任何语言描述，嘲讽力max。

2.	发售半年，跨过暑促，没有打过一次折扣，坚挺的88元。

3.	不知是作者故意删的还是真的没有人做出来，网络上找不到一丝攻略的迹象，只有社区讨论中非常零星的卡关讨论。是的，这个游戏非常难，而且只能靠你自己玩通。

4.	社区讨论串中有人问：“这么棒的游戏能不能加个成就系统呀？”
作者答：“我觉得我的游戏不需要成就系统。”

5.	通关后的cast表中最后写了这么一句话：“I don’t love all of you , but I would if I could”


开发者stephen为什么要这么做？其实原因也很简单，他制作游戏并不是想卖钱，只是想把自己的作品交给真正适合这个游戏的玩家去玩。而效果也很明显，评测区每个打通了的玩家都在高呼incredible、masterpiece……此处省略一万个形容词。

……
OK,还是谈谈游戏神在哪吧。

[h1]Thinking out of sausage[/h1]

Stephen’s sausage roll本质上 就是一个推箱子威力加强版，目的很明确：把地图中的香肠烤熟。从推箱子中，1x1面积箱子的一个点需要到地图中某个点上，变成了1X2的香肠正反两面、也就是4个点分别刮过地图上烤炉点仅且只能一次。要说推箱子游戏因为机制过于单纯所以导致过多的谜题存在着一定的重复度，那么本作在推箱子中强化出来的机制则可以催生出千变万化不同的谜题。

觉得这样的机制简单吗？其实硬核解谜玩家会觉得……真的还是挺简单的嘛，当然，作者没有止步于此，他的才华在这里才真正表现了出来。游戏中并没有靠这种机制堆积出千变万化的谜题的数量来折磨玩家，每个谜题的精致程度才是游戏中最亮眼的地方。同样是几根香肠，障碍物，烤炉组成的地图，不同的关卡就是完全不一样的思路。作者几乎把在这个游戏中的基础机制中翻出了无数不同的花样，设置在了每一个谜题中，让人在形状相似的每一关中都能发出连连的惊叹：我怎么之前就没想到可以这么解呢！

没有任何一个谜题是看一眼就能解出来的
也没有任何一个谜题是花上几个小时还解不出来的

当然，作者没有止步于此，游戏的深度也随着进程的推进而不断进化。一共6个章节，每个章节都会引入一个新机制。其实“进化”这个词似乎用的不对，因为游戏中的机制从来没有变过，只是在之前的关卡中，这些“新机制”一直存在，但作者并不鼓励也不需要玩家使用这类技巧。而当每一章刚开始时意识到这些机制的存在时，都会仿佛打开了新世界大门一样，卧槽居然可以这么玩！

简单剧透一个机制吧，不喜的人跳过：“3D推箱子”中“3D“的意义，随着游戏中段高度的引入，1X2的香肠变成了1X2X1的立体物件，玩家控制的小人可以走在香肠上方滚动，头上也可以顶着香肠。小人手上的叉子也随着游戏的推进产生出了各种意想不到、但又合情合理的玩法。

……

Stephen’s sausage roll最强大的地方就在于：机制简单容易上手，谜题却千变万化玩出了深度。

劣质的解谜游戏有哪些问题？
重复性高，难度却低，还没遇到挑战已经倦意十足；
画面浮夸，谜题的难度不在机制本身而在“画面这么花我TM根本没看到那藏在犄角旮旯里的解谜道具”；

……

Stephen’s sausage roll其实很像Jonathan Blow的见证者，没有浮在水面上的剧情，只有几句似懂非懂的哲学句子。不过见证者得益于它得天独厚的第一人称视角和开放世界以此玩出了很多脑洞谜题。Sausage这款游戏则基于它永恒不变却极具深度的机制，脑洞更少，更多的是逻辑上的纯粹性，很难说孰是孰非。我个人觉得这样更加能让玩家获得单纯地从逻辑层面上思考，推理，解开谜题上这一系列过程的美丽，一样具有所谓的升华感。

一个优秀的解谜游戏，就是要做好谜题，这个目的很单一，但也很困难。Stephen’s sausage roll在解谜的深度与难度上都呈现出了完美的状态，它很单纯，单纯到我很难把这个游戏安利给其他人（好歹你加个成就系统行不行啊），不过它也确实只适合那些真的乐意去挑战困难的核心解谜玩家。

如果没有Jonathan Blow先生钦点这个游戏，恐怕作者的高冷程度真的会让作品无人问津吧？[spoiler]以及赞美@结城偶像安利我这个游戏[/spoiler]

我为什么喜欢解谜游戏？因为游戏本身便是一种交互性强的艺术，而解谜，是一种玩家与开发者之间不需要语言的交流，通过绞尽脑汁克服优秀精致的难题获得的成就感，会由衷地赞美同样深思熟虑设计出来这些谜题的开发者。这是跨过种族国家，从最根源处进行的心灵沟通。我想，能看到玩家在自己制作的游戏中全身心地投入思考的样子，这就是所有优秀独立开发者制作游戏的初心吧。

[h1]Thanks Stephen, thanks for your sausages.
I feel like I am a sausage now.[/h1]

24619360.review:
Wow. 
Same as with many people here, I'd initially heard about this game from Jonathan Blow. He'd been touting it as incredible for a while, but in a way that you couldn't quite tell if he was being serious or not. Add to that the fact that all the promotional material out there also makes you question if this is even a real game or not, and it being relatively expensive among its puzzle game peers, I was a bit weary.
Well, I've just finished playing through the whole thing, and I can tell you it's not a joke at all. In fact, [b]it's the best puzzle game I have played to date, hands down.[/b]

I clocked in just slightly over 40 hours, which should give you an idea of how meaty this game is. The mechanics have so much complexity to them, and the game goes sooo deep in exploring every single little intricacy of them, it's ridiculous. And it does so with the utmost elegance. The amount of times I went to bed in awe of a puzzle I'd solved earlier is so large that I lost count.

One big thing that is so remarkable about this game is how contextual its mechanics are. In the majority of puzzle games out there you have common game interfaces used as a vehicles to explore unrelated abstract concepts. For example, in Braid you use basic Mario 2D platforming as a vehicle to explore time mechanics. But the time mechanics have no intrinsic logical connection to your little guy jumping around or picking up keys and whatnot. Which is fine, but it's so much more impressive when there is a logical connection.
In Stephen's Sausage Roll, just about everything you do makes sense with common real world physics. The way you interact with the sausages and the environment all looks like it should logically work, with few exceptions.

If you're a puzzle game lover then this is a dream game.

If you're still unsold, check out the Giant Bomb quick look. It's pretty okay in giving you an idea what it is, and in not giving away spoilers. But know that that's just the tip of the iceberg, and there's so much stuff beyond that.
