24153950.review: 10/10 best sausage rolling game I've ever played, and absolutely brutal

24121578.review:
Before I start this review, let me make something very clear: this is a puzzle game lover's puzzle game. 99% of the enjoyment that this game has to offer is simply the excitement that comes when you finally figure out how to solve a difficult puzzle. There is no form of progression in the game other than moving from one puzzle to the next, and the graphics, music, and story, while fitting for the purpose, are minimal. So, if you require some form of external motivation to stay interested in a puzzle game, I can safely say this game is not for you.

Got that? Good. Now I can talk about why Stephen's Sausage Roll is the greatest puzzle game I've ever played, and what exactly it does that makes it so great.

The creator of the game, Stephen Lavelle, is no stranger to puzzle games. He has released hundreds of short, experimental games, including many puzzle games, on [url=http://www.increpare.com/]his website[/url] for free. He also released a previous commercial puzzle game, English Country Tune, which is available on Steam. He even created an open-source puzzle game engine called PuzzleScript, which many other game developers have used to create simple web-based puzzle games. But it's clear that Stephen's Sausage Roll is his most ambitious project to date.

At first, it seems ridiculous that this game could have possibly been four years in the making. When you first boot up the game, you are greeted by a silly menu theme and a title screen that looks like it was made in 15 minutes in Photoshop, complete with stock fonts. Combined with the absurd topic of the game (who in their right mind would make a game about [i]sausages[/i]?), you might begin to suspect that the entire game and its surrounding praise is just an elaborate inside joke if you didn't know better. But as soon as you create your save file and enter the overworld map, you begin to realize what makes this game special.

The first aspect of the game that immediately strikes you is the player character's movement. The only keys used for movement are the arrow keys, but it as not as simple as a press on one of those keys creating a movement in that direction. Your character wields a giant fork as big as the character itself, and while it is invaluable in helping push sausages around, it also restricts the ways that you can move. If you want to move in a direction that is perpendicular to the direction that your fork is pointing towards, you first have to rotate your fork so that the fork is now parallel to the direction you want to move in. At first, this system can feel clunky and frustrating, and simply entering the puzzles on the map may prove to be a challenge, as you have to align yourself and your fork with the ghosts on the map in order to enter the corresponding puzzle. After a while, though, the movement system begins to feel natural, and you get to appreciate the depth that this system allows for.

When you do manage to enter a puzzle and the surrounding terrain falls away to leave room for the level, you realize the second aspect of the game that stands out: that it's really, really, hard. The goal of each puzzle is simply to grill each sausage on the level to perfection, with no square inch of the sausage raw or burnt. A sausage takes up an area of 2 by 1 tiles, with each tile of the sausage having a top and bottom that can be grilled separately for a total of 4 cookable segments. The sausages can be grilled on the various grill tiles in the level, and each segment must touch the grill tile only once in order for it to be perfectly cooked. Despite the simplicity of these rules (which are actually not even stated in the game, you would normally have to figure them out through trial and error), the puzzles that are created with them are fiendishly difficult. It is all too easy to accidentally push a sausage into the surrounding water when trying to move, burn a sausage by moving it in a direction you shouldn't have, or get yourself in a situation where it is impossible to progress because you placed a sausage in a location where you can't retrieve it. You mercifully get unlimited undos to reverse any mistakes you made, but oftentimes the biggest challenge is figuring out how to get the sausages to the grills in the first place, and that is where the game's design comes into its own.

Stephen's Sausage Roll descends from an old Japanese computer game called Sokoban, which literally means "warehouse keeper". In Sokoban, you have to push crates onto their required target locations to complete each level, similarly to how you push sausages onto grills in Stephen's Sausage Roll. Despite this heritage, Stephen's Sausage Roll plays very differently from Sokoban. Sokoban's levels are highly claustrophobic due to their narrow corridors and the inability to push more than one crate at once. By contrast, Stephen's Sausage Roll's levels tend to have few walls, and you are able to push more than one sausage at once. More importantly, though, while Sokoban's challenge tends to come from figuring out the exact sequence of pushes required to complete the level, Stephen's Sausage Roll's challenge comes from figuring out a broader concept that arises from the game's mechanics.

Stephen's Sausage Roll only introduces new gameplay elements once per world, and the new gameplay elements feel like a natural consequence of the existing ruleset rather than something that was added because the existing puzzles were getting boring. For example, the second world introduces walls that you can stab sausages against, allowing for a new method of transporting them that helps get them out of sticky situations, but also prevents you from rotating your fork. The third world explores the consequences of adding a third dimension to the game, letting you roll on sausages by getting on top of them and letting you stack sausages on top of each other, but also introducing three-dimensional obstacles that are even more fiendish than the ones before. Despite the simplicity of these additions, the different challenges and strategies that they allow for are vast, and the possibilities are always fully explored before adding another mechanic to the game.

As of this writing, the game costs a full thirty US dollars, so some might be worried about the amount of content that you get for the price. Fortunately, there are many hours of enjoyment you can get out of the game. I like to think that I'm pretty good at puzzle games, and it took me 32 hours to finish every puzzle in the game. That's less than a dollar per hour, which is a very good value proposition for anybody who enjoys their time with puzzle games. There are actually only 86 puzzles in the game, which doesn't seem like a lot, but that only speaks to how well-crafted the puzzles in the game are. There are no 'filler' puzzles that are just basic applications of principles that you already knew, and puzzles aren't wasted to teach you those principles without providing a significant challenge, either. Every single puzzle will give you that 'aha!' moment that is the joy of all puzzle game fans.

In conclusion: if you enjoy puzzle games, then Stephen's Sausage Roll is a must-play. The puzzles may be very difficult, but if you persist long enough to solve them on your own, the feeling of satisfaction you'll get from them is unrivaled. And for those who think games today are too dumbed down: this is probably the least dumb game you'll ever play. Be ready to think [b]a lot[/b] when you play this game!

If you don't like puzzle games, don't buy it. If you don't have money, wait until it is on sale. However, I will say that personally, this was completely worth the price.

Stephen's Sausage Roll takes Sokoban and adds a hefty dose of mechanical complexity to pretty much every part of the formula. The changes both extend and limit the player's abilities in ways that are extensively -- but not exaustively -- explored by the game.

Like many good puzzle games, this one is best played until frustrated, then left alone for a while, and returned to. I did make it through without hints or walkthroughs, though after getting stuck on a relatively early level I considered writing a planner. In the end, setting the game down and picking it up again over the course of a week got me moving again.

Generally, the levels that I found most troublesome were ones where a new mechanic was possible to use but not required to finish the level; I'd find myself focusing on using the newly available mechanic rather than solving without it.

22763331.review:
A truly brilliant puzzle game. It takes the mechanics so much further than you would imagine, to the point there are genuinely "Oh my god, did that just happen?" moments. I got 30 hours of thoroughly enjoyable play out of this and can see myself playing it again at some point, so it was worth every penny. I have only positive points to make:

- Very challenging puzzles right from the get-go.
- There *is* a learning curve - a very well crafted one - it just starts you off high. I'd say the level of difficulty is consistent throughout (given that you are also learning as you go).
- There are a lot of puzzles.
- The puzzles are meticulously designed such that they all have very interesting, completely different solutions and you can see how everything was arranged to make that solution and only that solution work.
- Pretty much every puzzle twists what you know about the mechanics (some will have you proclaiming "This is impossible!" before you *get* it).
- Every puzzle is super satisfying (to the point I'm shouting YESSSSS after each one).
- The graphics and audio are very well designed to not get in the way but also add a lot of character.
- Exploring the overworld is very enjoyable.
- You truly feel like you've improved as a puzzle solver by the end of it - there's a very definite evolution in the way you think about the puzzles.

There was almost a point early in the game (maybe 2-3 hours in) where I could have stopped playing, simply because I couldn't see where it was going. If you get past that hurdle, you'll be glad you did.

Perfect for puzzle fans. Couldn't recommend it enough. Also recommend having a friend playing the game as well so you can talk about ideas and spur each other on. If you're not sure, give it a try.

22742279.review:
Stephen's Sausage Roll is a puzzle game by Increpare. 

In any of the puzzles, there is not a single thing to distract you from getting to the solution, not necessary the solution, but the knowledge you gain after solving a puzzle. Every little detail is put in place with great care and has a purpose to it, so much so that you can complete solution through thinking about and finding out what those details mean and where they would play a roll. Many of the levels seem pretty hard or even impossible at first, but the game lets you trust it -- it wouldn't be in the game if it were impossible. 

No new mechanic is added throughout the game, yet the game constantly surprises you with its already rich mechanics, every substantial aspect of which plays some roll somewhere in this game. All of the mechanics are intuitive and none of them are abstract, they all connect together and except for one, none of them is independent from the rest. 

The game frequently drives you to a state where you have to doubt everything you trusted and reconsider everything you ruled out. Many levels need not only one but several moments of epiphany, some of which wouldn't even be needed in the particular level you reach them in, but are a natural result of the interaction between your mind and the level. It takes your mind so deep in the universe of ideas and possibilities that you forget the simplest of actions once you have the solution. 

Stephen's Sausage Roll is probably the best puzzle game ever made and it's a treasure full of awe. It doesn't try to deceive or distract you through fancy narrative and graphics. There is no hand-holding, no tutorial, no easy levels to make you feel you're making progress. It doesn't waste your time, yet there is more than enough time to be spent solving all the puzzles. It's filled with as much precious content as possible. There is no secret mechanic, hidden area or unnecessary complexities that make you feel betrayed. With all its difficulties, everything you need is in front of you. It's as honest and true as a game can be.

22654864.review:
Stephen's Sausage Roll is the latest puzzler from Stephen Lavelle (English Country Tune). It's a"block moving" game and a premium-priced indie. It's also flat-out amazing.

In SSR, you guide the player around an over-world with nodes representing discreet puzzles. When you land on one, the world drops away into a smaller puzzle area. There you're tasked with sliding and rolling raw sausages around the board in an attempt to grill both sides evenly via the strategically placed hot grill tiles embedded in the ground. Roll a cooked side of the sausage over the grill again and it's burned...game over. Roll it off the level and it's game over. The puzzles are ingenious. The puzzles are challenging. The puzzles are addictive.

SSR sports a raw, minimalist asthetic with vibrant, morphing colors and an abstract soundtrack. It looks rough in stills, but is absolutely charming in motion. Controlling your character is strange, as it doesn't adhere to traditional tank controls as you might imagine. Instead movement is absolutely relative to the direction your pointing in. There's a learning curve, but it comes together and makes sense when you start to understand the finesse needed to "thread the needle" around sausages and environmental obstacles.

As mentioned, the game is challenging as hell. Even from the start. One nice related feature is the ability to take back moves, one at a time with the Z key. Even after a level fail (rolling sausages into the water / burning sausages) you can execute this option, alleviating frustration when you're stringing together moves to set up a level clear.

I think SSR looks incredible. It absolutely nails the low-fi aesthetic. Nails it to the wall.  All you have to do is look at the Game Over screen to recognize this is all intentional.  Just look at that font! If someone didn't legitimately have the talent to pull off successful visual design, there's no way they'd out themselves by choosing that font style. It takes confidence and deliberate intent to visually create something on the level of Stephen's Sausage Roll.

Reviews are saying there's a TON of content on offer here. 30+ hours of evolving mechanics that keep the game fresh with new ideas even late game. Still, a $30 asking price for a game that looks like an itch.io project might be a bridge to far for many. Totally understandable. I opted in after reading some rave reviews coupled with the praise heaped on it from the puzzler dev community itself. Jonathan Blow (Braid / The Witness) described SSR as, "one of the best puzzle games ever made, or one of the best video games ever made”

So I held my breath and dropped $30 on the game. I'm REALLY glad I did as it's pressing all the right buttons for me. I went to bed thinking about game tactics and solutions. I woke up and got ready for my day thinking about tactics and solutions. And here I sit at work, wishing I were at home executing tactics and solutions.

Kind of funny how the best and the brightest of the year can wind up being the games you never knew you wanted. Much like Stardew Valley, I didn't know about Stephen's Sausage Roll until days before release. Yet I can quite comfortably see both placing on my end of year Top 10.

22637781.review:
Conceptually, I like Stephen's Sausage Roll quite a bit. I think that the core gameplay mechanics are fun and interesting. The window dressing is fantastic- talking about rolling sausages and grilling them is worth a laugh by itself. The puzzles are simply sublimely designed and make use of every single bit of sausage-rolling complexity the game's ruleset has to offer.

All of this is a shame because the game is so relentless in its difficulty that it ruins the whole experience. The puzzles start at a pretty good level of challenge- you might not understand all of the rules and strategies quite yet, but the scope of each discrete puzzle is small enough that you quickly figure out strategies and work toward a solution. You'll eventually solve each of the puzzles in the first area and move onto the second, where the puzzles follow a similar formula and scope. All of this is fine until you reach The Great Tower- a Jenga-stacked tower of 8 sausages that represents the game's first difficulty wall. Suddenly, you can no longer solve a puzzle through simple trial and error- you need to develop a plan of experimentation and strategy of attack to even begin to understand the scope of the puzzle.

Provided you do in fact grill all of the sausages that compose The Great Tower, you will find that it isn't simply a one-off "boss fight" of sorts- this is your new sausage grilling reality, as numerous puzzles in the next area follow its newfound scope. And that's basically where I draw the line! I like puzzle games, but the level of difficulty here moves from simple brain-teasers and logic exercises to full-fledged logistic projects in their complexity. It also feels that as the game goes on it loses a bit of its focus- instead of each puzzle tightly focusing on a mechanic, much of the later puzzles require long strings of execution and moves. It no longer gives you that "a-ha" moment without lengthy experimentation. It's simply too much work and effort for anybody but die-hards.

Ultimately- although I really do like the game's ideas, I really don't think that I could recommend it to anybody.

22622365.review:
I've finally grilled all the sausages. This is the best puzzle game. Every individual puzzle is just so damn clever, no two puzzles are alike, and there are SO many puzzles. If you enjoy puzzles, you will like this game.

The difficulty comes because no two puzzles are solved in the same way. The game's mechanics are the same from the start until the end, involving rolling sausages and walking around, but each puzzle puts you in a scenario where you have to use the same old mechanics in a novel way.

Usually, this is difficult because you didn't understand certain consequences of how the mechanics work. But once you flail around for a while and solve a puzzle, the consequences were clearly logical: how could you not have thought of that? Argh, it was right there.

This makes the puzzles feel straightforward and more importantly fair, even though solving them may be a struggle. There is no busywork of pushing around boring things that don't matter to the main idea of the puzzle. When you get an idea for how to solve a puzzle, it's quick to see whether it works. When you get the right idea, you KNOW it works, because the puzzles don't have unrelated filler and they're easy to think about. So the problem just becomes having the right idea, which is a LOT of fun if you like puzzles.

I don't think most people are going to complete the first area in the 2-hour refund time. I certainly didn't. That's a shame, because although the first area's puzzles are good for what they are, and are necessary to teach how the game works, they are probably the weakest part of the game. As you learn things about how the game works, the puzzles keep getting better and better until the end. It's an extremely impressive body of work.

There is also an engaging story, which was pretty surprising! It starts off extremely vague, but later in the game there's more story text between every one or two puzzles. Getting more of the story was a good motivation for solving some more puzzles.

I really liked this game. And I'm definitely going to get some replay value out of it: I've already forgotten how most of the puzzles work!

If you're a fan of difficult puzzle games that let you take the initiative to explore the ruleset and ideas contained with in, I can't recommend Stephen's Sausage Roll enough. 

Pros:
+Some of the best design I've seen in a game, both in terms of puzzles and overall structure.
+The introduction of new mechanics over time works extremely well, as soon as you feel like you've learned all you can learn about one idea, another one is introduced that surprises you with all its possibilities.
+The distinct lack of tutorials might seem off-putting for some, but the game is better for it, as it lets you know that it expects you to take initiative in figuring things out on your own.
+Many puzzles are very challenging, but never tedious. All of them have their own twists and turns on the "core concept" of the area.
+Music is very ambient, which works well to not be obtrusive while working on puzzles.
+There is a day/night cycle in the game which keeps more difficult levels from seeming like you've been staring at the same collection of blocks for hours on end.
+Visual style is very helpful, it lets you easily see at a glance how the level is laid out by tile count.

Cons:
-The content is finite.

Get this game and roll some sausages.

22561474.review:
I'm only about 40 sausages in, and this is already one of the most beautifully designed puzzle games I've ever played. I've noticed that a lot of commenters in the discussion feel like the positive reviews aren't helpful, so instead of just getting all poetic about how awesome this game is, I'm going to try to be a little more concrete.

1. This is a game for puzzle-game lovers. If you're not into puzzle games, it isn't going to thrill you. If you love puzzle games, but aren't super into Sokoban-style games (like me), you are going to end up surprised by how much you love this. It's basically Sokoban-like, but it takes the concept to a whole new level. I will try to be specific:

a) The sausage fork is both a tool and a handicap. As a tool, it allows you to push sausages in directions other than straight ahead (and do other things I won't spoil). As a handicap, it constrains how you can situate yourself to push sausages.

b) A sausage itself has two sides, and each push (with exceptions I won't spoil) rolls it to the other side. This creates extra constraints when trying to grill each side only once. Sausages are also two tiles long, which creates extra constraints based on both orientation (vertical or horizontal) and grilling all four parts of the sausage.

These additions to the basic Sokoban-like mechanic result in a very large design space for difficult and epiphany-producing puzzles. Great puzzle games are about two things: constraints and topography. SSR hits a sweet-spot (or a spicy-spot if that's your preferred sauage type) for a simple system of rules that produces a wealth of complexity.

But a wealth of complexity doesn't automatically result in a great puzzle game. There also needs to be a great designer who mines that huge space of possibilities for the most devilish ideas and unintuitive twists. And this is what's getting SSR so much critical praise. The levels are designed for maximum epiphany and minimum repetition of tricks. It's a subtle kind of novelty, but every puzzle gives you something new.

2. Can you discover how awesome SSR is within the refund period? Possibly. If you do two or three puzzles on the second island and your mind isn't blown, though, it might just not be your thing. My particular mind was blown pretty early on. I found myself skipping puzzles and then solving them on a background thread as I was driving somewhere. That's a pretty sublime feeling. Another sublime feeling is the sense that a puzzle is simply impossible, follwed by the discovery of a solution. This has happened to me constantly while playing SSR.

3. The art style. I see people calling it "simplistic" and "primitive", which I think misunderstands it a little, because it implies that it's unintentional or the result of inability. My sense is that the game looks the way the person who made it wants it to look. Part of the fun of the game is the campiness. If it were logs or plain cylinders instead of sausages, it wouldn't be as endearing. And if the world and its sausages were rendered more realistically, I don't even know what I'd think. It would probably be creepy. Again, though -- if the art style isn't to your taste, then it will probably detract from the enjoyment for you.

4. The price. I write games myself, so I'm probably biased, but I really like seeing indie games being priced higher than a crappy Domino's pizza. I don't know how many hours it will take me to finish the game, but I've seen people with over 30 hours in it who aren't done yet. A buck an hour doesn't seem like a lot to me, when I often spend twice that rate for a 45-minute TV show. I can understand not wanting to spend that much, but I don't really get why people feel offended by it. It's a market. The seller sets a price and people either buy it or don't. It ends up being either a good decision or a bad one, and that's pretty much that.

Summary: I love puzzle games as much or more than I love sausages, and this is likely to be one of my favorite games of all times. We have entered the Golden Age of puzzle games, friends, so pony up the 22 quid and bask in its greasy, sizzling glory.

Stephen' Sauasage Roll is a possibly one of the best thought out puzzle games I've ever played. Unlike other Sokoban-like puzzle games, I feel like I could solve almost every puzzle I've played so far a second time without having too much trouble, and every puzzle has felt different. The puzzles in this game are about understanding what your options are, and they all feel much more open than other box pushing games. This means that you can't brute force a solution, but it also means that you're more open to experiment with the mechanics (which you'll have to do a lot). After every puzzle I felt like I understood the game better for having solved it, even if only a little bit. I encourage anyone who likes puzzle games, or even those who just enjoy thinking, to try this game.

EDIT: I just beat the game and I feel like I should add a few things, although I promise to keep it spoiler free. Firstly, The ending to the game is very poetic and almost entirely satisfying. To explain it any further would be a disservice to Stephen's work, so you'll just have to see it for yourself. I can say, however, that it was a perfect way to end the game.

Secondly, the amount of thought and planning that must've gone into this game as a whole more than justifies the asking price, and if you count the time I spent think about the puzzles outside of playing the game it come out to about 2 days worth of "play" time. Although I may have gotten stumped a few times I always managed to find a solution with relative ease the next day, usually by considering an entirely different angle to approach the problem from. 

Also, the slow reveal of new mechanics was paced perfectly. One in particular Was so unexpected and mind blowing that I had to undo my moves and watch it happen a second time just to comprehend what had happened. I you thought this game was simple then you are sorely mistaken.

Overall, I have to say that this game is easily the best puzzle game I've ever played in my entire life. I've heard this called the Dark Souls of puzzle games, but I think it'd be more accurate to call it the Citizen Kane of puzzle games instead.

Stephen Lavelle, you are truly a master fo your craft!

[i]Original review is everything below:[/i]
Alright, this game put me in a tricky spot for two reasons listed here:
[i]

22501275.review:
It is very difficult to write about, Stephen "Increpare" Lavelle latest game: Stephen's Sausage Roll. The first difficulty is that it is a puzzle game and, as such, its core virtues are in its mechanics and in its level design. The second difficulty is that discovering the mechanics is an integral part of the game so keeping things spoiler free without being vague is tough. Let's try though.


The incredible elegance of Stephen's Sausage Roll comes from the fact that from the very start of the game to its very end all the rules of the world are there, but the complexity and richness of the rule set are only unveiled little by little, because new puzzles offer the potential for new situations where new rules are discovered (and are often needed to solve the puzzle). To make an analogy, if you are able to walk on water but are in a desert, you can't know you have this ability. So Increpare would make you start in the desert, then later would put water in a level that would at first feel impossible until you realize you can in fact walk on water.

My analogy is not very good, because the beauty of this game's design is that, more often than not, it's not the apparition of a new component that allows a new rule to be discovered, it's using new configurations of known elements. Also the abilities and rules you discover do not come out of left field, they make sense and if they might be a little too surprising, levels are carefully designed (with funnels or bread crumbs) to guide you toward their discovery. Something that works with my analogy though is that an alarmingly high number of levels will at first make you believe they are impossible to solve. I can't tell you the number of times I discovered a new level only to mutter (or shout...) "What???? How???"

While I am slowly running out of superlatives, it is also important to note the game manages the feat to be both very long and very dense. Those familiar with Increpare's other puzzle games, be it the number of free games on the puzzlescript platform he created or his previous commercial product, English Country Tune (also highly recommended), know his aversion for fluff such as mundane tutorial levels, so these sausages are pure meat from the get go. There is no such thing as a level that does not bring something new to the table in form of an original challenge, so solving any single puzzle is extremely satisfying. Reaching this point is the fruit of a strenuous work of distillation that lasted years with dozens and dozens of levels that got discarded and all the rest going through multiple iterations and fine tuning to be sure that, as often as possible, they provide challenge the whole way through their resolution.

To give a sense of the scope of the game, I played through the final build in about eighteen hours, while I knew just about all the mechanics and had played most of the levels in an earlier build a year or so ago, so I would expect people new to the game to easily go past the 30 hours mark. It is important to note because, at $29, the price can feel pretty steep for an indie puzzle game, but that's probably less than $1 per hour of pure gameplay and level design meat. Another way to look at it is that it is without a doubt the cheapest masterclass in puzzle design money can buy!

With this package also comes a thin and strange narrative that works hand in hand with the structure of the game, and an aesthetic which at first seems a bit crude and rudimentary, but really grows on you with its surprising care to details such as weather effects, day/night cycles and a soundscape periodically haunted by some minimalist musical tracks. It should also be mentioned that the control of the character takes a little time getting used to, but pretty quick it becomes apparent as to why it is the way it is. Every move matters.

22500450.review:
I was fortunate enough to become a tester for this gem of a game. Stephen's Sausage Roll is one of the most carefully designed games I've had the pleasure of playing. It's also one of the most challenging puzzle games I've ever played.

You begin shipwrecked on a mysterious island. Your only tool is a strange fork and all you can do is move forward, backward, and rotate. You're given very little information, but you'll soon find yourself in one of the game's devious puzzles. Your goal? To roll sausages over to the grill tiles placed on the floor and cook them. That's it. SSR forgoes complex mechanics seen in other puzzle games for simplicity and elegance. You may not see how you can use your limited moveset to accomplish what you want, but there is always a way.

Aesthetically, Stephen's Sausage Roll is a succulent treat. Colorful low-fi visuals, soothing accompaniment, a day and night cycle, and an overall tranquil atmosphere. There's also some cryptic story to be uncovered in notes you'll find throughout the island.

Now, as I said before, this game is hard. The puzzle-solving is based on experimentation and your familiarity with the (sometimes hidden) mechanics. Luckily the game is very forgiving in this regard. You're given access to a variety of puzzles at the start of each area and you have unlimited undos available for when you mess up (and this will happen). SSR expects you to learn from its challenges and it's very adept at teaching you new things through the puzzle solutions you discover (sort of like The Witness).

Overall, this game is really something special for puzzle game fans. I admit I haven't made it that far in the game, even with all my hours of play, but I'm excited to see what awaits. Sausage is tasty and so is this game.

Just played the first few levels, so take this with a huge grain of salt as I literally just started it. I also made a video to show off the gameplay, which you can see here: https://youtu.be/KbWNYiWCzn4

The controls take a lot to get used to and feel very cumbersome at first, which isnt a good sign for a puzzle game. However, the difficulty in controls were very well integrated into the (excellent) level design and game mechanics, creating some extremely devious challenges. If you want to sink your teeth into a puzzle game, this will give you a lot more meat than you can chew.

Word of caution though, the base mechanic does revolve around "pushing blocks" (or sausages in this case) and its not too far off from other similar games like Sokoban. Stephen's sausage roll is adding another level of complexity onto a very familiar subgrenre (block pushing puzzle games), making it very challenging, but it is also not really pushing for anything new. And the price point is sort of the sore thumb here in regards to that. From what I can see so far: 

Is it a good game? Yes. 
Does it deserve your money? Absolutely. 
Is it worth 30$? That is entirely up to you, in regards of how much you value challenge in your puzzle games.

I love challenging puzzle games and I am looking forward to biting into this eventually when I have more time for it, but I appreciate new ideas more than I do just challenges, and going back in time, based on what I played so far, I would not recommend myself to buy it at 30$.

It has a gimmick title. You are probably weary of the joke comments and bad punning. To you people I say this: SAUSAGES.

22497202.review:
This game, huh? What a package! 

Right from the word go this game had me in love with it. The opening menu makes me warm and fuzzy each and every time I load it. I sit there and smile, whilst it plays out. Then there's the overworld music. It reminds me of Firelink Shrine in Dark Souls. It's eery, yet safe.

The gameplay and puzzles are fantastic and will have you pulling your hair out, consuming you when you can't play it, begging you to go back as soon as you can because you think you know the answer.

SSR is like the Dark Souls of puzzle games. It doesn't explain anything to you, it doesn't hold your hand but let's you just go about your thing. Lastly, it gives you a good, old fashioned challenge, which until recently with games like Snakebird and The Witness, were pretty rare.

I'm super impressed and highly recommend SSR. Now go roll some sausages!

22496117.review: You have to play the game to understand it and solving each puzzle is really satisfying. Even the puzzle selection screen is kind of a puzzle. I like it. :-)

22494745.review:
One of the most challenging puzzle games out there, but never unfairly so. The mechanic of just pushing, rolling, and navigating the sausage to its grill is intuitive, and surprisingly deep. Recommended!
Plus, it has sausages, which, as a German, I love very much.

22494276.review:
Do not be fooled.
This game will invade your subconscious. 
You will play for hours. You will burn many sausages. You will curse at your computer. 
You will swear "That level is impossible."
You will rage-quit. 
You will still be thinking about it days later. 
You will start the game again, and attempt a level again. 
You will finally solve it.
You will yell in triumph, and smile.

Then you'll start the process again on the next level.

It's absolutely brilliant. And silly. And frustrating. And weird. 
It is an amazing and fun puzzle game that you'll not stop thinking about. 

It's will also make an excellent conversation starter. And possibly conversation ender as well, with people walking away with strange looks on their face. You'll be branded a weirdo, as you profess your love of rolling sausages around on the ground. 
But you won't mind. Because you'll know the truth. The true beauty that is Stephen's Sausage Roll.
And you'll walk away from them, smiling to yourself, eager to get back to the game to solve that one nefarious puzzle that you've been thinking about all week. 

Stephen's Sausage Roll.

39428271.review: This game may look unassuming but it is hands down one of the most clever, satisfying puzzle games I have ever played in my life. I waited for a sale because I was unsure whether I'd just end up frustrated, but after playing it I would have been happy even paying the full price. Highly recommended.
